patient_information: Age: 72 years Sex: male Occupation: farmer Location: Laos
chief_complaint: Extensive, painful verrucous skin lesions on the left foot and lower leg
history_of_present_illness: Onset: 10 years prior to admission Description: A leech bite on the dorsum of his left foot resulted in a small painless red nodule that developed into a verrucous lesion over time. The lesion slowly increased in size and spread up to his knee. Recent changes: Three days before admission, the ankle became painful and swollen.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: Recent travel to Laos Vector exposures: No reported vector exposures or sick contacts
vitals: Temperature: Normal Blood pressure: Not reported Heart rate: Not reported Respiratory rate: Not reported Oxygen saturation: Not reported
physical_exam: Skin: Grossly swollen, hyperaemic and feel hot. Several cauliflower-like masses and oval plaque-like lesions on the left lower leg and foot. Foot: Painful and swollen with a bad odour Ankle: Painful and swollen
labs_and_diagnostics: Cbc: Not reported Microscopy of skin scrapings: Characteristic brownish, round, thick-walled sclerotic cells typical of chromoblastomycosis Pcr from skin tissue: Positive for Fonseca pedrosoi, F. monophora and F. nubica
differential_diagnosis: {'chronic verrucous skin lesions': 'Sporotrichosis (Sporothrix schenckii) and chromoblastomycosis', "mycetoma ('Madura Foot')": 'Eumycetoma or actinomycetoma, characterized by fistulating lesions discharging granules', 'malignant conditions': 'Squamous cell carcinoma, sarcoidosis, chronic eczema and psoriasis'}
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: Antifungal therapy with itraconazole (400 mg/d for 7 days monthly pulse therapy) and surgical debridement of all lesions Outcome: Lesions healed uneventfully with some residual swelling and hypopigmentation
final_diagnosis: Disease name short: Chromoblastomycosis Confirmation method: Positive PCR for Fonseca pedrosoi, F. monophora and F. nubica Evidence: Characteristic brownish, round, thick-walled sclerotic cells in skin scrapings
